1.content:
Hannah stood in the open door of her new apartment. It feels weird to be on her own, but she's getting used to the idea. She moved far from her hometown in Montanna, where she had grown up her entire life. Now, in the great New York City, where any opportunity is a possibility, she looks for a job so she can begin her own life. She is working at a local diner, trying to save money to pay off her school loan, and to help pay for her new apartment.

She often wonders about the friend who she had believed had been more than that. They had sparked a passion that was undeniable their junior year in October. It lasted until that September, when they were off to college. She wondered what became of him. If he found his true love. If maybe they were meant to be together. She wasn't sure if they were soulmates, but she misses him, and wishes that maybe they could meet, and then she could see for herself if the burning flame of passion they had created has finally blew out.
1.title: New Opportunities

11.content:
Luis walked out of the New York City airport, with his luggage in hand. He had a smile on his face, and a huge ball of happiness inside him. He couldn't wait to find a job for him, so he could begin his new life. He'd need to begin a job so he could support himself. It was a good thing that he had the money, and the family to help him out, and get an apartment, and enough to pay for two months in advance. He knew that the opportunity was here...in New York City. He could feel it.

He went into the twenty-one story apartment building, and walked over to where the elevators were. He pushed the up button, and waited almost ten minutes before he got one that was going up. He was on the twelveth floor. He smiled. He liked being in high places, where he could overlook things. He was syked. All he needed was a small job to help with the rent and other necessities, and he'd be fine. All he needed now, was a newspaper.
11.title: Open Oportunities

choices: Going out to explore the city
111.content:
He unlocked the door to his apartment, and smiled. He saw that his furniture had arrived. They weren't exactly in the positions he wanted them, but..you can't complain. He set his luggage down on the floor, setting his keys, and his handbag on the counter in the kitchen. He picked up his luggage, and walked into the room that would serve as his room. He came back out, and shut his door, remembering that he had forgotten to shut it.

He went into the living room, opened the windows, and hooked up her stereo. He turned it on, and moved his living room furntiure to the way he wanted, he went and moved his bed and dresser. He came back into the living room, and almost collapsed on the couch. After having a few beers, he went and took a shower.
111.title: Moving In

choices: He decides to wait until tomorrow
1111.content:
Luis, even after taking a shower, still felt tired. He figured it was traveling on the plane, and moving around his furniture. He turned off his stereo, and flopped himself on the couch.

He laid there, looking at the ceiling of his new apartment, his new home, and just thought about many different things. How his life had changed, how he had tried to love a new girl, but found himself finding a girl that could live up to Hannah, and failing. He'd have to find her. He knew that she was somewhere in New York City. Even if it was humungous, he hoped he would find her.

He tried to think about finding a job, while continuing to look for a major job. A job that would become his career.

He put his hands behind his head, and blinked his eyes a little, feeling them getting heavy. Before he knew it. He was out like a light.

[] [] [] [] []


His eyes flashed open. He didn't remember the dream, but he remembered it had something to do with Hannah, and the prom. He shook his head. He sat up on the couch. It was dark, and with the bright lights outside, there were no stars. One thing he missed about Montana. He got up, and made himself a pot of coffee. It was almost three in the morning, and there were still people walking the streets, laughing, talking, hanging out with friends.

He walked to the window, and watched the people below walk across the very crowded sidewalk. He sighed. He wished his friends would have come with him. They could have played football in a park. Spilt into two teams and played against each other, like they did in college.

He turned, and found that his coffee was done. He poured himself a cup, and ran his free hands through his hair. He needed to make some friends. He'd go crazy if he didn't have anyone to talk to.
1111.title: Friends

they settled to get married, but the girl's first husband appeared from the dark rocks and with explosion se parated teh two.

It is a lazy, relaxing Saturday afternoon. You decide to take a hike. Maybe it will help to relieve the stress of everyday city life. Maybe it will help you to set aside your financial worries for a while. Certainly it will help you to escape the pressures and demands you face when surrounded by others - loved ones included.

You dress in comfortable clothes and sturdy shoes. You travel light, taking nothing but a walking stick and a canteen of water.

And for once, you decide to take the path less-traveled.

Howdy, pilgrims!

I've received two e-mails in the past 24 hours from members of the Shelter, asking about my forthcoming novel, Offspring. I very much appreciate the interest. However...maybe I'm nuts, but I really don't want to turn this forum into a pitch mechanism for my books. I already have other means for promoting my work. This site is intended to promote the craft of writing, and provide a supportive environment.

Okay, I realize that a few members of the Shelter will eventually buy one of my books because: A. They feel a connection B. They like my style of writing, C. They pity the author.
And when they read the story, I expect they will like it very much, or dislike it very much. I doubt there'll be much middle ground.

Please keep in mind that I've been particpating in WC long before I ever sold a book. I didn't come here to beg people to buy my work. With that in mind, I'll tell you a few things about Offspring.

The book's release is still a few months away, (Oct. 6 release date) though some people have already, and inexplicably, pre-ordered through Amazon.com. Don't ask me why. I honestly can't imagine why. Heck, the cover art isn't even up on Amazon, yet!

I digress. I sold the book in March, 2004. The wheels of publishing turn slowly, uh? Truth is, I wanted to delay publication until my retirement from the day job, which by the way, now coincides with the release date. Don't you love it when a plan comes together?

Since selling the first book, I've had several conversations with my publisher, the Thomas Dunne imprint of St. Martin's Press, regarding additional stories. I'm very pleased to announce that I sold two additonal books to St. Martin's just last month. This allows me to tell the story in the form of a trilogy. We've also discussed additional spin-offs, as many as two additonal trilogies, after Offspring runs its course.

Offspring falls into one of three genres, depending upon ones perspective. Supernatural epic, dark fantasy, or horror. It has a few rather graphic moments. The good guys are, for the most part, regualr Joes. Flawed in myriad ways. Course langauge upon occasion, thoughtlessness, vanity, disdain for their fellow man... and capable of great heroism when the need arises. Sorta' like some very real people I know. The bad guys are...bad. Really bad. I mean, "fifty miles of south Texas blacktop road" bad.

11112.content:
He turns on the living room light, and slumps into the couch. He doesn't feel like going out. He would probably get lost, since the city is totally different at night, than at day.

He takes a few sips of his coffee, and relaxes. He has to order that paper once the sun comes up, and people who weren't partying the night before are actually awake and moving.

He puts his socked feet on the coffee table, and looks at the small pile of Sports Illistrated Magazines on the table. I could've been a great football player. One that all people would look up to. He saw a picture of a man in a Philidolphia Eagles uniform, holding his helmet with a large grin on his face.

He thought of what it'd be like, to be a famous football player, and wear his twenty-four jersey for all to see. To this day, he still didn't know why he hadn't gone along with that career.
11112.title: Football hopeful?

111121.content:
Giving in to his persistant eyelids Luis let them shut. He fell into a deep sleep and didn't wake up until the early morning light filtered through the living room. His neck was stiff, from the position he had been in but he still had a smile on his face.

"What to do, what to do?" Luis thought to himself.

Shuffling into his bathroom he decided to hop in the shower and start hitting the pavement for a job.

Humming while he got dressed his mind kept floating to his days in high school, football and of course, Hannah.

Maybe I should try and look her up Luis thought as he finished putting on his shoes.
111121.title: Sunny Days

choices: He asks her to come along with him
They go an do something together
1111211.content:
He grabs his keys of the kitchen counter, and opens the front door. He locks, and makes sure the doors are shut tight, and then walks down the narrow hallway to where the elevators are.

He takes a deep breath as the doors open and he steps out. He can feel the heat coming through the open doors. He smiles at the man behind the desk, in front of all the mail slots for each room of the hotel. Some are empty, while others are full.

As he walks out the door, someone collides with him, and they both fall to the ground.

As he falls, he sees whisps of blonde hair. He notices that whoever knocked into him, was beginning to stand up.

"I'm so sorry! I was looking in my purse, and I wasn't even paying attention! God I'm so sorry!" It was a woman's voice, and it sounded delicate and soft.

He looked up, and stared at her for the longest time. She moved her long blonde hair from her face, and put it behind her. She looked up at him, and the same concentrating face appeared over both of them.

"Hannah?" The ravishing blue eyes had caught him. He knew them from somewhere, and Hannah's face instantly popped into his mind.

"Luis?" A smile appeared over her face, but it was an unsteady smile. She wanted to make sure it was him before she got all excited.

"Come here! Geeze, I never thought I'd bump into you like that!" He said reaching out to her, and pulling her in for a hug.

"Luis! What are you doing here? I never expected to see you!" She said excited. Her blonde hair came back into her face, but before she could move it, he moved it for her.

"You have such pretty hair Hannah. I see you're letting it grow longer." He complemented.

The last time he saw her, it was just below her shoulder blades, and now it was almost down around her buttocks, but it was thick, vulouptuious hair. It was cut even at the bottom, and it was a beautiful golden color.

She blushed. "Thanks. You got taller, and more cuter it looks like." She said, giving him her smile.

"Hey, if I got more cuter, it's only because you got more beautiful." He knew it sounded kinda cheesy, but it was things he used to say to her to make her smile.

She raised an eye brow and laughed. "You and your cheesy sayings. Where are you headed anyway?" She said as she dug into her purse again, and finally, what it looks like what she had been looking for, she pulls out a hair scrunchie. She smiles, and pulls her hair back into a ponytail.
1111211.title: Bumping Into An Old Friend

choices: She tells him about her relationships
11112112.content:
She looked back up at him, after putting her hair into a ponytail. "Would you like to go out to lunch with me?" She asked. She smiled, and arched her purse strap up on her shoulder.

"Sure. That'd be cool." He said smiling. He put an arm around her waist.

"My waist your arm rest?" She said remembering the first time he had done that.

"Of course. It's so comfortable." He smiled, and they walked down the sidewalk, mixing with the hundreds of people walking down the sidewalk.

A small outside restaurant stood out. It was called Hope Falls. "Want to eat here? I've had some of their coffee. It's actually pretty good." Hannah said as they stood at the corner. People rushed past them. It was almost lunch hour, and the streets would be packed with people who spoke different languages.

"Sure. If you think it's good. It prolly is. Just don't set me up with something with some foreign name." They both laughed, and they found a small table, to wait for a waiter.

"So, what do you like best about New York City?" Luis asked as he took a sip of the beer her ordered.

"I love it here. Despite the occasional problem or two. It's really great. I love the diversity. I bumped into a guy who spoke Japanese. I think he swore at me." She laughed as she took a sip of the tea she had ordered.

"Well that sucks. I mean, it's worse enough to have some who speaks english swear at you, but when someone who speaks another language does, and you don't know what he said, now that's gotta suck." He took another sip of his beer, and held it in his hands before setting it back down.

He laughed, and looked up at her. He noticed the way she smiled at him. The way her hair hung in the ponytail, and the little hair that had fallen from it, and was now hanging in front of her ear. The little sweat beads that had formed on the--now--tan skin of her brow. Her eyes seemed to be searching him. Checking to see what had changed in him, and what had not.

"How have you been Luis? How was California?" One hand was on the arm rest, and the other was laying across her lap. She was trying to be composed, he thought with a smile.

"I've been great. California was cool. I got to be an architect like I wanted, but....it just wasn't like high school you know?" He replied. He hoped she would pick up on the fact that he had meant her.

"I missed you, you know. It seemed weird waking up, expecting to see you outside, waiting for me on the front porch. Or getting ready for a football game, and me getting ready in my cheerleading get-up. It was very weird for the first few years." She teased the handle of the cup with her fingers, and rang her right pointer finger across the rim of the cup. She looked up at him, with a look in her eye he didn't remember.

"It was weird for you not being there either. I tried to date a couple of times, but they didn't last more than the first date if that. I kept trying to make them seem like you. After awhile, I think they got the picture, and girls just didn't want relationships with me." He said as he fondled the bottle of beer.
11112112.title: Conversation

111121121.content:
She picked up her cup, and took a sip from it. He watched her intently. She looked up at him, and took a deep breath.

"I had quite a few boyfriends. I think the first were just a rebound from you. I know that sounds kinda weird, but I think I was going through a withdrawl or something." She stopped, and laughed. It was a half hearted, who-gives-a-shit, kinda laugh.

"After awhile, I believed then that I had to open my horizon as some might want to call it. I remember this one guy in particular. He was a senior when I was a junior. His grandparents were from India. He was really cute. We dated for about two years, before we found that our relationship wasn't going anywhere, but our friendship had tightend a lot. We were best of friends...." She let that last sentence trail off. With that way she said it, he knew that she wanted him to ask more about it, but in a way was kinda scared to answer.

He picked up his bottle of beer, fondled it for a moment, then took a sip. "You used it is past tense. You aren't friends anymore?" He asked, seeming to be more interested than he wanted to be. He set his bottle down on the table, and looked at her.

"He died two months after I was out of college. We had been broken up about ten months. It was in a car accident, involving his small truck, and a moving truck. He didn't even see him coming as he had crossed the intersection."

He sat a hand on hers, that had now clamped the handle of her cup. Her hand seemed to instantly release of the tension, and it relaxed. She let go of the cup.

Her eyes met his, and they stared at each other for a moment. She smiled, and pulled her hand back. "I had a few other relationships, but they seemed to turn more into friendships, and I kinda gave up trying to make any romance relationships."

It kinda ended that part of the conversation. He wanted to bring up some more on how she was doing, but the waitress came finally, and handed them what they had ordered.
111121121.title: Relationships didn't Equal Romance

After they finished eating they stood silently on the busy street. Hannah looked at her watch and exclaimed "Oh crap! I have to go, I promised a friend I'd go shopping with her."

Luis tried to hide his disappointment. Even after eating together, they still hadn't talked as much as he liked. He had missed her so much, and he wanted more time with her.

Hannah wrote her phone number down on a scrap of paper she found in her purse and handed it to him. "I'm sorry we didn't spend much time together. Call me?" Before he could say anything, she kissed him on the cheek and walked away hurridley.

He felt re-engergized after taking a shower. He put on a pair of shorts and a tank top, and flipped on his sandals. He searched through his small handbag, and found his sunglasses. He put them on, grabbed his keys, and locked his apartment door behind him.

The sun was decending slowly behind the tall buildings. He figured that he'd go to a bar and try to see if he could meet some people. Most of his friends were either in Montanna or in California. As he walked, he seemed to see every type of race on the sidewalk. He heard all different kinds of languages. It felt weird. When he was in California, all he heard was English and Spanish. There were few Chinese or Japanese, or European.

He finally got onto a road where it seemed that's all there was was bars and clubs. It was hard to move with the crowd of people swarming in and out of them. He tried to be as polite as he could, but after a few minutes, he gave up, and started shoving back. He guessed he'd have to be strong to live in New York City. No one wanted a sap who could easily be pushed.

111211121.content:
Luis tried to concentrate on what Mallory was saying at the moment, but his eyes kept straying to where Hannah sat. He watched the her beautiful blond hair sliding down her shoulders in wide abandon and her eyes...they were as cerulean and captivating as before.
As if she could sense his eyes studying her appearance, she looked away from the animated face of Mallory who was recounting her summer escapades as a child. Without thinking, Hannah turned her head and her gaze instantly locked with that of Luis.
The two of them watched each other in silence while the others continued with their conversation. A faint blush began to stain Hannah's cheeks as she realized how intensely he was watching her. ' He's still so handsome...and irresistible.' the thought passed restlessly through the maiden's mind, and for some reason, her heart began to wrench painfully in her chest. Could it be because she still loved him? Hannah disregarded the thought by telling herself,' I just haven't seen him in a long time. And we were good friends in the past. So, it's normal to have missed him.' The young woman dropped her gaze for a moment for she wasn't certain whether that was the truth. When she looked up, Luis was still looking at her. That was when a silent message passed between them;there was no need for words.
Slowly, the two stood up. Hannah excused herself from her friends, saying," Luis and I are just going to catch up on old times." Then, she strode to where he stood and off they went out of the bar.
Hannah's heart began to beat rapidly as they were leaving. What was she doing? Why was she doing this? 'I just miss him and naturally, I would like to know what happened to him all through these years.' Luis turned to her and she was positive that she would melt.
111211121.title: Poignant Feelings Resurface

Luis stared at Hannah, as he had been staring at her all night. He longed to pull her close to him and hold her there forever, but he wasn't sure what Hannah was thinking of him. He broke away from her steady gaze, glancing across the street.

"How about we stroll through the park?" Luis suggested suddenly. "It's always beautiful at dusk, I've heard, and it's a great place to catch-up."

Hannah smiled, for although she was scared by how much she was still attracted to him (it's only because I haven't seen him in so long, she thought to herself) the park was one of her favorite places...
1112111212.title: Stroll In The Park

11121112121.content:
"It's been a while. How's everything?" Luis asked wanting to know every detail.

He'd missed her, he'd missed their chats, the ones where they would stay up late just listening to eachothers problems. He missed hugging her, the feel of her skin against his, the warmth of her body pressed to him. He'd missed the way she would tickle his arm when they were both falling asleep, most of all, he'd missed their friendship. The way they could laugh about anything, understand everything they were talking about when most people didn't. He'd missed her.

"Everythings..good' she smiled "I've got a job, an apartment, my mom lives closer now. Not much to report on, my life hasn't been to eventful" she laughed, "What about you?"

As he watched the wind blow her hair from her cheek he smiled. "It's been alright. I mean, i have a job an apartment and my mom lives closer now" he winked.

Hannah laughed."What about your dad?" she asked.

"He passed away a year ago. Was tough but, you deal with it and i know this will sound cheesy but, i know he isn't gone, so it doesn't hurt as much. He's always here" he said pointing to his heart.

Hannahs face dropped, her eyes welled up. "I'm so sorry Luis" she said flinging her arms around him. "I should have been there for you. We were best friends. What happened to us?"

Luis could feel Hannah shaking as she cried, he'd forgotton how close he and her had actually been. He didn't want this hug to end, it reminded him of how it used to be.

"I don't know" he whispered holding her close.
11121112121.title: Read On...

choices: Find out more about her fiance.
111211121212.content:
Hannah wiped the tears from her face and smiled at Luis. She'd missed him, she'd missed the way he held her when she cried, the way his arms made her feel safe and secure like nothing could hurt her.

"I'm sorry about that" she mumbled rubbing her arms because of the cold.

"Hey its fine" he smiled, removing his jacket.

He passed his jacket over to her and wrapped it around her shoulders. His hand stayed on her shoulder. Their eyes met. Luis felt the butterflies in his stomach he got the night they first kissed. He wanted to go back to that. He wanted to start anew.

"You were the one. You know that right?" he asked putting his hand back down to his side.

"I know" she smiled

"See the hardest thing i ever had to do was let you go and i thought i was over it. I thought that i'd forgotten you, forgotten how it felt to want you, forgotten how it felt to be wanted by you, but i havent forgotten, if anything i know more now than i ever did. I don't want to freak you out or anything, i just needed to get it off my chest" he sighed.

Hannah smiled and placed her arm on his. "I'm glad you told me. You used to tell me everything. It's nice to think you can still trust me like that. I feel the same. When i saw you again tonight i got a pain in my stomach. I didn't know if i still loved you, or wether it was just because i missed you."

"and..." he asked.

"It's because i love you. I've always loved you, i always will love you, there's always going to be a place in my heart for you"

Luis smiled as he felt like a weight had been lifted off his shoulders. He'd waited long years to hear her say that again and here it was. He noticed she looked a bit glum.

"Hey...isn't love a happy thing?" He asked trying to lighten the mood.

Hannahs head stayed down, she was twiddling somthing on her finger. She looked up with tears in her eyes. Thats when he saw it.

The engagement ring.

111211122.content:
Throughout the next hour, each of Hannah's friends drifted away with a guy. Luis found himself alone with Hannah, just as he had wanted. After a semi-awkward pause, he spoke.

"So, Hannah, how have you been?" he asked.

For some odd reason that Hannah couldn't explain, the question warmed her. As she sipped her drink, she thought of how she should respond.

"I've been okay. I'm here with my own apartment, looking for a job, and I'm thrilled. Things seem to finally be falling into place for me." She told him. "What about you? How are you doing?"

"I think I'm about the same." he said with a smile. "I'm looking for a job, too. It's great to be here, you know?"

Hannah only nodded. After a brief silence she asked, "Luis, can I ask you something?"

He looked surprised. "Of course."

"Did you ever think about us? I mean, what might have happened if we hadn't gone our different ways?"
111211122.title: Alone At Last

choices: They go somewhere else to talk.
1112111222.content:
Luis glanced up at her and took a deep breath. "Yes, I think about it. All the time, actually. Why do you ask?" He answered, his voice deep and soft.

Hannah shrugged, not meeting his eyes. "I don't know. I guess I just wondered if maybe those two years meant more to me than they did to you."

Luis reached over and took her hand. "Hannah, look at me." When she did, he continued. "I remember every single moment we were together. Everything we did, everything we said. How could I not? What we had was amazing."

Hannah looked down at the table, not knowing what to say. He spoke again. "I didn't date in college, you know." She looked up at him in surprise.

"Why not?" she asked, almost whispering.

Luis held her gaze. "Because there wasn't anyone I met who could measure up to you."

"Oh, Luis," she said quietly, her eyes filling with tears.

"I was thinking maybe the park, or one of our places. I don't know really, I just didn't want to be in there. I wanted to be with you." He said quietly and softly.

As she listened to his voice, she noticed that it had deepened some, and had become more gentle. At least around her. He had tanned more since she had last seen him, and he still had those dark intense eyes that she always loved.

"I don't care. How about we can go back to my place, and I can make some dinner?" She suggested as they crossed the street, and walked along the busy sidewalk.

She smiled back, she was feeling her knees go week, but she kept walking. Here was this very hot guy walking with her, and he was her best friend, and high school loverboy. Hannah was awoken from a deep, content slumber the next morning by an obnoxious buzzing. She squinted, looking around. She saw a vibrating alarm clock sitting on the beside table and promptly slammed down on it, ending the incessant noise.

She was about to slip out of bed- but as she moved to get up, her head started to throb. Not only that, but she was in an unfamiliar bedroom. She groaned, lying down again. Face to face with Luis Armstrong. Hannah flinched- and then, the memories of last night started flooding back. The first sighting of him in years at the bar, the first kiss since then, their sweaty bodies moving together until they collapsed in exhaustion.

Hannah felt a rush of excitement thinking about it- tinged with a slight regret. Was there such a need to rush it? She wished she hadn't readily dropped her friends to be with him.. but it showed how much she still loved him after years apart. How did I ever forget Luis? she wondered, feeling a grin spread on her face despite her hurting hangover. She reached out to touch Luis's cheek, snuggling closer to rest her lips on his neck.

It wasn't long before Hannah sank into sleep again. But when she woke for the second time that morning, it was Luis stirring. Hannah glanced up. He was staring at her. She smiled, croaking, "Good morning Luis." he smiled back. "Good morning.." and moved down to kiss her bare neck.

Minutes later, they were kissing passionately, groping eachother, hardly coming up for breath. Before they could take it farther, Luis whispered in Hannah's ear, "I'll be right back." he pulled himself away from her grasp and slipped out of bed. Hannah sighed, impatient, but gladly watched the back of Luis, naked, walking to his jacket draped on a chair across the room. He pulled out a pack of condoms. As he returned, Hannah took in the front of his bare body and prepared to pounce.

But then he suddenly halted.

"What's up?" Hannah whispered, thinking he may now only have noticed the intense hangover she already felt.

There were four or five girls, he wasn't sure; the bar was crowded. But what he saw, he liked.

When he looked back up, however, the women were making a sudden move to the door. Something caught his eye.

A flash of blonde, above a hot silky red dress.

It can't be, he thinks to himself.

It can't be HER. He hasn't seen her in four years, hasn't even written her a letter, but for some reason, his heart starts to pound, his palms go sweaty.

And then, the blonde turns her head. It IS her, not twenty feet from him.

Without thinking, Luis leaves the bar, his friends, and his beer, and rushes out to catch her. He has an odd compulsion, a sense that he had to catch her now, or end up regretting it for a long time.

He dodges people, drunken and sober, and closes in on his target.

1121122.title: carpet time

choices: Hannah finishes vacuuming and takes a shower.
Hannah begins to vacuum when the doorbell rings again.
1122.content:
Hannah headed towards the bathroom to jump in the shower when she heard the doorbell ring. She rolled her eyes and turned back around to get the door.

"Hannah, you will never believe what happened to me today!"

"Anna -"

Without waiting for Hannah to invite her in, Anna Perkins let herself in, dropping her seemingly 20-pound purse on the floor, knocking over a house plant and spilling soil all over Hannah's freshly vacuumed carpet.

"Oh jeez," Anna laughed, "Am I clumsy or what? You will never believe what happened to me today, though!"

Hannah looked in disbelief at the pile of dirt on the floor she had just cleaned so carefully, but didn't have time to say anything about it as Anna rushed on to tell her story.

"Okay, so I'm at Sak's looking for a business suit for my interview next week, blue, I'm looking for blue, because I look really good in blue, and I pick out all these blue suits, and I'm thinking I can't decide between a long skirt and a short skirt, so I head towards the dressing room, and I walk right in without asking, and bump straight into this guy. It was the men's dressing room, can you believe it?" Anna giggled, and then went on. "Okay so I drop all these suits on the ground, and the dressing room lady is like freaking out about all the clothes because they might get wrinkly or something but this guy is SO HOT!"

"Wait a minute," Hannah finally interrupted, "You have a job interview next week? You didn't tell me that!"

"Yeah, it's with Parker and Barnes, but I'm pretty sure I'll get it 'cause my cousin works there, but anyway, about this guy. He picks up my clothes and hands them to me, and I'm like all flustered about it and I don't even remember what I said, but he smiled at me and I nearly died of the joy of it. So anyway, I go to the women's dressing room and try on all my clothes and I pick out this awesome blue suit, which turns out to be a short skirt with a jacket that would make anyone want to hire me, if you know what I mean! But anyway, after I bought the suit, I stopped by the yogurt shop to get a snack, and there is the guy, sitting at a table all by himself! I didn't want to be obvious, but I went over and sat with him and we had the best talk! Anyway, I invited him over tonight and I think we might go out to eat or something!"

Anna had to stop at that point to take a breath, which Hannah took as a good sign that she could safely begin to ask Anna questions without being interrupted.

"Um, Anna, don't you think you should be at home? Um, cleaning your apartment? Your roommates don't really seem keen on washing dishes and it really smelled when I came over yesterday," Hannah said, wrinkling her nose at the memory of messy Anna's living space, which was a stark contrast against Hannah's neatly-kept and well-decorated apartment.

"Well, that's the thing," Anna went on, "I wasn't about to invite him to MY house, so I gave him your address."

"What??" Hannah practically shouted.

"Hannah!" Anna whined, "You know I couldn't have a guy over to my place, he would take one look at my roommates and turn around and leave. Besides, this guy was totally clean cut, I can tell he goes for the organized and clean type."

"Well, Anna, you're NOT the organized and clean type, so why waste your time?"

"Well, duh, reason number TWO I gave him your address. That way he thinks that I live here and will think that I AM organized and clean."

"I can't believe you!" exclaimed Hannah, "I JUST moved in and I'm all hot and sweaty and tired and you invited a guy over to my house."

"I know, but it'll just be this once, maybe just a few times after this. Look, I'm going to run home and change and get ready, he should be here at 7 tonight, okay? I'll be back in like an hour."

Hannah glanced at the clock, which read 5:45. Anna was notorious for being late and flighty, which was precisely why Hannah was not more surprised at the occurances of the evening, but Hannah was not about to greet Anna's man only to wait with him for an hour while Anna finished re-applying the tenth shade of lipstick.

"Anna, I swear to you that if you are even one minute late, I will never talk to you again!"

"I promise!" Anna replied, and grabbed her weight-lifter's purse to leave. "I gotta run, but I promise I'll be back by 6:59!"

With that, Anna ran out the door, and Hannah could hear her 5-inch clogs stomping down the stairs. Hannah rolled her eyes again, and got the vacuum out to take care of the dirt on the floor.
1122.title: Anna's Story

choices: Anna's guy is at the door.
Someone else is at the door.
11221.content:
After a careful inspection to make sure that she had gotten all the dirt out of the carpet, Hannah put the vacuum back in its storage space and walked towards the bathroom to take a shower. She paused momentarily before turning the water on to make sure that she would have no more interruptions. Sure that she would be left alone, she took a long, cold shower.

After her shower, she dressed in Luis's old high school jersey, which he had given to her the day he left for college, and a pair of boxer shorts that had likewise belonged to Luis.

She had been feeling somewhat lonely since moving into her new apartment, not only because she hadn't dated in nearly a year and wanted the presence of a guy, but also because it was the first time in four years that she had lived by herself with no roommates.

She settled into her couch with a magazine and put a cd on to relax to after her hard day of cleaning. At 6:44, the phone rang.

"Hello?"

"Hannah, it's me, please don't be mad, but my car won't start and none of my roommates are home! I'm going to take the bus, but that means I'll be a little bit late. Please don't be mad, it's not my fault! Just tell him I had to run an errand or something!"

The connection started to break up at that point, static nearly drowning Anna out.

"I gotta go, I'll be there in a few!"

"Wait, Anna! What's his name?"

But it was too late, Anna had already hung up, and just in time for the doorbell to ring. Apparently, he was early.

Hannah hung up the phone and went for the door.
11221.title: A Call From Anna

choices: Read from Hannah's point of view.
Read from Luis's point of view.
112211.content:
When she opened the door, she stared disbelieving at the figure before her.

"Luis!" she gasped.

"Hannah..." Luis said, obviously confused. "What... what's going on? What are you doing here?"

"I... Anna gave you my address instead of hers because her roommates didn't do the dishes and I..." Flustered, Hannah looked down at the floor and stopped speaking, for lack of an idea of what to say.

"Nice shirt," Luis said, laughing at the peeling number 42 of his old jersey.

Hannah looked up and blushed, and then, realizing that Luis was still standing outside, invited him in. He gave her an awkward hug at the door, and then came in and looked around.

"This is a really nice place," Luis said, "How long have you lived here? I knew you were in New York, and I had hoped we could hook up, but I didn't realize it would be so soon."

Hannah laughed. "Uh, yeah, it is a little odd. I just moved in this week, actually, and Anna was a little over-excited about having a place to invite guys over to. What are you doing here? Last I heard from you, you were out in California finishing your architecture degree... What brought you to New York?"

"Well, nothing, yet, except the hope that I'll find a job and some excitement," Luis laughed.

Hannah looked at him critically and saw that he was still very good to look at, but more mature than he had been when she saw him last.

"How's your mom -" They both asked each other the same question at the same time, and each burst into laughter.

"She's fine -" They did it again and laughed even harder.

"You look beautiful," Luis said, interrupting the laughter with a serious smile at Hannah.

Hannah blushed again, and the comfort that she had begun to feel suddenly disappeared as embarrassment took its place.

"Um, thanks," she replied, in almost a whisper.

Luis, intent on bringing her out of her sudden shell, began to ask her questions about her job and her life in New York. After a while, she began to open up and they were deep into conversation when Anna walked in, without knocking.

Hannah stood up guiltily, but wasn't quite sure why. Anna looked at the two of them and for once, wasn't quite sure what to say.

"Uh, do you two know each other?" she asked.

"Well, um, Anna, this is Luis Armstrong, remember when I... um, my friend from high school," Hannah replied awkwardly.

"No way," Anna declared in all capitals, "Fabulous 42??" she shrieked, glancing at Hannah's jersey.
112211.title: The Meeting

choices: She decides it'd be better if she left
1122111.content:
Hannah felt herself blush. She wasn't sure why. She hadn't seen Luis in four years, and now he was back in her life, and he looked damn good. He seemed to age like wine. The older it gets, the better it becomes. She felt herself blush over the thought. "Well, I see I'm known around here. All your friends know about me?"

Anna spoke up with a smile. "Of course. In our first year of college, she told us all about the two of you. She told us about your first kiss together, and how you went to prom. She even showed us the prom picture. You two look so good together!"

Hannah stood up. She cleared her throat. "Well, the two of you have a date. I...uh...will be down at Hot Mamma's if you need me." She went into her room, and a few minutes later came out in belly button showing jeans. With a yellow tank top. She grabbed her purse from the table, but felt a strong hand on her shoulder.

"Don't go. It wasn't really a date, just a...get together thing." His deep intense eyes stared deep into her ravishing blue ones. "I...uh...would like you to stay." He turned and faced Anna, who's large brown eyes were wide open and full of dispair and happiness. "That is, Anna if you don't mind." Hannah watched as Anna took a deep breath. "No. I don't mind. If you don't Hannah."
1122111.title: Caught Up

choices: Hannah takes Luis to her favorite art museum.
Hannah takes Luis to a coffee bar.
11221111.content:
Hannah shrugged her shoulders and agreed to stay.

Quickly recovering from the fact that the guy she had hoped would be her next fling was the ex-boyfriend of one of her best friends, Anna grinned and thought to herself that she would make it her goal to get Hannah and Luis back together. She knew that Hannah hadn't dated much since Luis, and she suspected that it was because Hannah couldn't find anyone equal to Luis.

"So, whatcha guys wanna do?" Anna grinned.

Both Hannah and Luis were feeling uncomfortable, eaching knowing that the other was thinking about their past, Hannah knowing that Anna's grin meant something devious, and Luis knowing that Anna had thought that they would be going out on a date.

"Um, well, I'm new in town," Luis replied, "So I'm going to let you two pick someplace cool to take me."

"Hannah?" Anna asked, with a sly grin, "What do you think?"

"Well, we could go out to eat..."

"Okay," Anna said, evidently the moderator of the evening. "Let's go to that Italian place on the corner of 13th and Warren... It's all you can eat and Haggle is playing tonight!"

"That sounds great," Luis smiled.

Hannah offered to drive, which left Anna scrambling for the backseat so that Luis would be sitting right next to what Anna thought ought to be the love of his life.

They would have driven to the restaurant in complete silence, had it not been for Anna's incessant chatter from the backseat. Neither Hannah nor Luis were much in the mood for talking, at least not in front of Anna, and both seemed to be somewhat absent-minded, answering Anna's questions and responding to her exclamations with half-hearted nods and occasional smiles, punctuated with a yes or no every once in a while.

They got to the restaurant and sat down to order when Anna grabbed her pager and gasped excitedly at the message it beheld.

"Oh my gosh Hannah, it's Brian! I can't believe Brian is paging me! I have to go call him RIGHT NOW!"

With that, Anna got up and ran to the public phone to call Brian.

"Anna's perpetual crush," Hannah explained to Luis with a smile, "She's been waiting for a call from him for days."

Luis laughed, the absence of Anna instantly making him feel better about the situation.

The waitress came over to their table, ready to take their order, and when Hannah looked over at Anna and motioned for her to come back to the table to order, Anna practically shouted across the restaurant for Hannah and Luis to go ahead and order without her, that she wouldn't be having anything.

After the waitress had left with their order, Anna bounced across the room and shrieked embarrassingly loudly.

"Hannah! Brian is picking me up in like 5 minutes! We're going to Alba's! I'm going to wait outside for him... You two have a good time!"

Anna ran outside to wait for Brian and Hannah and Luis looked at each other and laughed.

"Hannah..." Luis started, "I just wanted you to know that when Anna invited me over, it was because she told me that a bunch of people were getting together, and not because she and I were going to go out on a date."

"Oh, it's fine," Hannah insisted, "I don't have a problem with it... I mean, it's been like four years." Hannah laughed nervously.

"I know that," Luis replied, "I just didn't want you to think that I was in the habit of going out with girls I just met."

"Well, that's not really any of my business anyway," Hannah said, quietly.

"Of course it's your business," Luis protested, "We've been best friends all our lives!"

Hannah and Luis continued making small talk throughout their meal, and sat quietly listening to the live band when they started playing. After dinner, Luis asked Hannah if she wanted to go somewhere else for a while, since it was still early. Hannah agreed, so they got in her car and started driving around.

"Where are you taking me?" asked Luis, with a smile.
11221111.title: The Dinner

choices: They go home - the conversation is implied.
112211111.content:
"You'll see," Hannah said mysteriously, with a smile.

They drove for quite a while until they were almost out of the city when Hannah pulled into a parking lot in front of a small, but neatly kept building. The front of the building was nearly all glass, but from where they were, Luis couldn't tell what was inside it.

As they walked toward the building, Luis looked around him curiously, and decided that wherever they were, it definitely wasn't the typical city setting. Though at the edge of the city in a neighborhood that not at all matched the actual place they were at, Luis saw a green area that looked very much like a park behind the building, and flower gardens on the sides.

"This is a really beautiful place," Luis said to Hannah.

"I know... I love this place."

They went inside where Luis discovered that Hannah had taken him to an art museum.

They walked through all of the rooms, both enjoying the company of the other, their mutual background in art and design making conversation both intelligent and interesting.

"I want to show you something," Hannah said, as she motioned for Luis to follow her into a tiny side room. There she pointed to a large painting on the wall. "Read the sign next to it."

Luis stepped closer to read the sign and saw Hannah's name neatly listed as the artist. He stepped back and looked at the painting again and smiled.

"Wow, that's incredible... How did you get a painting in a gallery?" he asked.

"Well, this gallery likes to show the work of local artists in addition to historical pieces, and one of my old professors introduced me to the curator a few years ago, who liked some of my work and asked to purchase some for the museum."

"Wow, that is so cool!" exclaimed Luis, "So you're like something of a local celebrity, huh?"

Luis grinned at Hannah.

"Whatever," Hannah said, playfully rolling her eyes at Luis, "Let's go outside, there are a bunch of cool sculptures throughout the gardens."

Luis unexpectedly grabbed Hannah's hand and led her outside. Hannah may have blushed, but certainly didn't pull away.

They walked outside until it got dark, looking at all of the sculptures and catching up on all the time they had been apart.
112211111.title: The Art Museum

choices: Hannah does have something for dessert.
Hannah doesn't have anything for dessert.
1122111111.content:
"It's been so long since we've seen each other," Luis said wistfully, "I've really missed you."

"I know," replied Hannah, "I'm sorry I wasn't better at keeping in touch. It's not that I never thought of you, it was just... well, you know, you just get busy with school and work and things just... happen."

"Do you have a boyfriend?" Luis asked, abruptly.

"Um, no," Hannah replied, "I haven't really met anyone I liked."

Luis smiled to himself at the irony of the fact that Hannah was living in one of the biggest cities in the country and hadn't found anyone she liked.

"What about you?" Hannah asked, after a few minutes of silent walking.

"Oh, you know, you spoiled me for other girls," Luis teased, and laughed, as Hannah blushed and then laughed too because she couldn't help it.

"But seriously," he continued, "I guess my top priority has been school, which hasn't left me a lot of time for socializing. I know you think I was probably a bit of a party guy in school, but I honestly wasn't. I can't even tell you how many nights I spent the night in the computer lab, trying to finish extra projects so that I would be sure of graduating with honors."

"I know exactly what you mean," replied Hannah, "the week before graduation I thought I was going to have to order a larger sized gown so that it would fit over the keyboard permanently melded onto my hands."

Luis laughed and Hannah smiled at him.

"You crack me up," laughed Luis.

"I know," replied Hannah, with a flirtatious wink and a smile thrown Luis's way.

Luis let go of her hand and put his arm around her shoulders, pulling her close and ruffling her hair.

"Luis!" Hannah reprimanded, frowning to try to hide a smile. It felt a lot like the old times that Hannah had missed so much all during college.

"C'mere," Luis said, as he pulled Hannah toward a bench and sat down. Hannah sat next to him and laid her head on his shoulder when he put his arm around her. The two sat in silence until it was dark out and they could only barely make out each other's outline.

Hannah began to feel the bug situation overwhelming her as she tried to be subtle about shooing the mosquitos away, but finally said, "Hey, I'm being eaten alive here... do you want to go back to my house for dessert? I think I might have something..."

"Yeah, I'd like that," Luis said, and stood up to go. He grabbed Hannah's hand again and walked close to her until they got to her car and drove back to Hannah's house.
1122111111.title: Catching Up

choices: Luis Calls Hannah the Next Night
11221111112.content:
"Hmm..." Hannah said, as she looked through the small amount of items in her refridgerator, "Well, I -thought- I had something for dessert." She opened the freezer, but didn't see anything there, and checked both the cupboards and the cookie jar as well.

"Well," she continued, a little embarrassed, "I really did think that I had something...."

"It's okay," laughed Luis, "let's make something. Remember when we used to bake cookies at your house and I made you promise not to tell the guys?"

"Yes, I remember," replied Hannah, drily. "You were such a baby," she said with a smirk.

"Yeah right, look at you, Miss Luis-I-Don't-Want-to-Climb-Trees-in-my-New-Dress!"

They both laughed and Hannah pulled out a cookbook to find a recipe.

"Well, I'm pretty sure I have all the ingredients for peanut butter cookies if you think you're not sick of them after all those times we made them back in high school," Hannah said.

"Mmmm, peanut butter, my favorite! I am all about peanut butter cookies!" Luis said.

Hannah pulled all of the ingredients out of her cupboards and they mixed and stirred and poured and sifted, occasionally "unintentionally" dropping flour or other messy ingredients on the other.

They laughed as they baked, and after they had put the cookies in the oven and cleaned up the mess, they both flopped down on Hannah's couch.

"I know we haven't done much today, but I am exhausted!" said Luis.

"I know," agreed Hannah, "before you came over, I had just put everything away and cleaned my house."

Luis took a few moments to look around Hannah's living room and dining room, which he could see from where he was sitting.

"Can I see the rest of the apartment?" Luis asked.

"Of course," smiled Hannah, "if I can get up."

Luis stood up and grabbed Hannah's hands and pulled her up.

"There, how's that?" he grinned.

"Okay okay," Hannah groaned, and led him into her bedroom. "This is my bedroom," she explained, and then showed him the small room off the bedroom. "And this is my all-purpose room," she laughed, "I do all of my painting and sewing and design work in here, and this," pointing to another door, "is my bathroom. Not much, I know, but I fell in love with the hardwood floors in here and the view. It's absolutely beautiful on a clear day."

"No, it's really nice," said Luis, "I'll have to bring you over to my apartment, which is much tinier than yours, and not half as clean!"

"Well, if you are anything like what you were in high school, I'm sure it'll be clean soon. You always were a neat-freak," Hannah said.

"I know, one more thing we have in common."

They laughed as they went back in the kitchen to check on the cookies. Being that they were done, Hannah took them out of the oven, piled them on a plate, and they went outside to her balcony where they sat on Hannah's tiny hammock and ate them.

When all of the cookies were gone, they looked at the plate in surprise and laughed.

"Oh my gosh!" laughed Hannah, "You are the only guy in the whole wide world that I would EVER eat that many cookies in front of!"

"Oh stop it," Luis laughed in return, "If anyone should be embarrassed, it should be me. I ate WAY more cookies than you did!"

Hannah took the plate back inside, and Luis followed her in.

"Hannah, I should probably get going," he said, looking at the clock. "I have a job interview kinda early tomorrow morning..."

"Oh... okay," Hannah replied, a little disappointed that he was already leaving, even though she knew she had to get up early the next day for work.

"Can I see you again tomorrow?" Luis asked, hopefully.

"I'd like that," smiled Hannah, "Can I come over to see your house?"

"Well, that doesn't leave me much time to clean," Luis laughed, "But I guess since it's you..."

"Okay," said Hannah, "I get off work at 4:30 tomorrow afternoon, call me after that okay?"

Hannah wrote her phone number down on a piece of paper and gave it to Luis before she walked him to the door.

"I'll see you tomorrow then," Luis said, and gave Hannah a huge hug.

"Bye," Hannah replied, as she watched him walk out the door and down the hall.

She shut the door and then leaned against it and sighed. A lot had happened that day that she would need to think about. She hurried through her shower and climbed in bed so that she could think things over.
11221111112.title: Dessert, and the Making Thereof
